title: Bridging Human and Machine Learning: Using discrete Markov Chain Monte Carlo with People to explore human categories
segmentation: So today I'm going to talk about bridging human and machine learning using discrete Markov chain Monte Carlo with people, and we're going to use this to explore the structure of human categories.
So the Pascal funding went to basically, uh, paying for my postdoc salary for six months.

But I collaborated with a lot of researchers all over UK and in the United States as well, and I'll be mentioning them throughout the talk and at the end of the show, everyone that worked on the project with me.
So basically, the approach of this.
Work is in line with this work in cognitive science that uses computer science and machine learning methods to understand how the mind works, and in particular, Oh no.

Sorry, and in particular the the in particular the question that we try to address using these computer science methods is the challenge that the mind has, which is what they might have to do is it has to take noisy, uncertain and ambiguous input from the world and it has to extract useful, meaningful structure that underlies this noisy input, and so that's the underlying challenge that computer science methods have used to try to understand.
And so, for example, here's some examples of the types of challenges the brain and the mind face.
Like for example, you have to construct 3D representations from 2D images that hit the retina.
You have to recognize complex sounds from sound pressure waveforms that hit the air, hit the ear you have to.

In psychology, you have to learn languages from just hearing a limited set of sentences, which is a really small subset of all the possible sentences that are allowed in language and you are able to learn language this way.
We learn categories from just seeing a few limited examples from the category.
So there are lots of examples of where we as beings have to infer structure in noisy environments.
So the use of Bayesian probability theory and machine learning methods to address this question and cognitive science has been used in three principle ways.
So the three main ways that you can use probabilistic methods in machine learning for cognitive science problems are first as a benchmark.
So what you can do is you can take machine learning probability theory to answer, impose what the ideal rational solution would be to a given cognitive problem, which is what's the ideal learner or.
Rational thinker, what would they do in this noisy probabilistic environment and you come up with that ideal rational solution?
And then you compare that with actual psychological behavior and the any similarities or discrepancies between these two can be used to infer some principles underlying how the mind works.
So that's one way you can use probabilistic models as a benchmark for ideal rational behavior.

Another way that these models are often used is that they're used as a direct model of the psychological process, so you can use these and say maybe this actually simulates something like the algorithms that the brain is using.
The 3rd way is also we can use these methods, computer science methods as tools for measuring psychological mental representations without any assumption about.
The principles underlying them, or the algorithms underlying them, says just use the tools for measuring complex representations in the brain.
So today my project is going to be looking at this third way of applying computer science to cognitive science question.
And I'm going to look at it in terms of identifying how this how we represent the structure of human categories.
So it's going to be used as a tool for investigating human categories.
OK, so.
So what are categories?
So concepts and categories that kind of kind of use them interchangeably, but roughly the idea of a category is we made basically use them to make sense of anything in the world.

Well, how we make struct find, structure and complexity you can think of a concept as a mental representation that picks out a set of items in the set of items, then becomes a forms the category that is described by a concept and so.
Throughout our everyday lives, we're constantly referring to our categories and we're constantly updating them to create new ones as well.
Degrees can spend over any life concepts so they could determine what we think is healthy in terms of food and activities.
It can help us determine who is our friend who's our foe, what's what we like, and what we don't like.
What's an efficient mode for traveling or what we should do during the day?
I'm categories basically determine most of our thoughts and behaviors in life.
These are just very, very small subset of examples.
So.
In today's talk, I'm going to talk to you about some background on category representation research in cognitive science and talk to you about the challenge that this project.
Addresses, which is the difficulty of measuring real life categories in real life environments and what how it does that is we.

We found this new method of measuring people's representations of categories using Markov chain Monte Carlo sampling methods and what we did is we adapted adapted the MCMC method such that it can be used to measure human representations in real life complex environments.
So.
First of the background, so I'm going to go over some basic overview of category research insight in cognitive science.

And so when basic feature categories, is that the assumption is that they are not rigid, so you can have so first of all, which category something belongs to will be determined by the features of that item.
So that's a basic assumption of categorization based on some features that you can quantify about an item.
You can then extract a category relationship to it, and the ideas membership is not rigid, so it is not like things are either in a category or not.
So you can represent this nonrigid membership to category with probability.
So that's often how people represent category distributions that the probability.
So for example, for these items X, these images of potential dogs, you can say the probability that the category is is dog for these pictures, given a picture, X is whatever, so it doesn't.
That's the way a lot of researchers represent category the notion of category so.
So two types are very Canonical models of category representation.
People have used in cognitive science.
They're known as prototype and exemplar models.
And so prototype models are assumed that you represent your category as just the iconic prototype of that category.
So you just pick 11 representation.

That kind of captures the essence of the features of that category, and on the other extreme people, other researchers proposed that you have this exemplar model, where really categories are representations of all the members of that category, and what happens is these two.

Different ways of categorizing new items so when a new item comes along and you want to categorize the new item, the prototype model says you're going to compare that that new item to the prototype only and how similar it is to the prototype will determine how likely it is the new item belongs to that category that you're assessing, whereas the exemplar model says when you encounter a new item, you will compare that new items to every single example of that category that you have in your head, and then the similarity between the new example and.
All existing examples of the category will be used to determine category membership.
So it's kind of too extreme views, but of course these models can somewhat be combined.
Multiple exemplars can be grouped together to form, like lots of prototypes, and you can extrapolate between these two in trying to model how people represent categories, but so.
So another feature of most category learning research in cognitive science has been that it uses really basic stimuli, so it uses like basic shapes, very unnatural, and so you can.
The reason for this is that it's easy to control foreign experiments, right?
It's hard to design an experiment without confounds using natural stimulus.
We people use these very artificial stimuli.
Also, it's easier to interpret the results because this way everything is very simple and easily quantified.
So people like using these artificial stimuli.

But the problem is that real life concepts and categories very are very far and different from those simple shapes that I just showed you and real life objects that belong to and concepts that belong to real life categories are difficult to measure their high dimensional.
And often higher dimensional complex and a key thing is that the features that describe any item that will be categorized, the features often cannot be interpreted in dependently.
You can't just take one feature and say, well, this is probably category of.
Something, because, for example, let's look at these two frowny mouths, and if you want to try to categorize what expression this face goes into.
Do you really want to see the either?
Which way the eyes are looking at so like frowny mouth with kind of slanty eyes.
Looks more angry and frowny mouth with kind of droopy eyes looks more sad.
So the point is that the feature.

Is how the features depend on each other is very important for categorization and this results that there will be extremely high dimensional stimuli that you have to quantify and represent when you're trying to understand how people represent real life categories.

OK, so this is a different application that I worked with researchers at Decision Technology, which is a sort of academic and also part corporate company and they do market research models and we used MCMC to see if we could come up with a better way of predicting consumer preferences and So what we did, we did a bunch of simulations on the theoretical models we showed that MCMC does much faster and much more accurately in terms of predicting.
Preferences for products compared to the normal pairwise random choice.

So we had a bunch of simulations showing that was better and then we tested it on real participants and So what we did was we used wines and we categorize the wines to have different features and we asked.

We ran them through an MCMC experiments where they were asked which wine features they preferred, and then we asked them doing a random pair wise choice experiment, seeing which one they prefer to compare these two methods in terms of assessing consumer preferences.

summarization_data.sent: So today I'm going to talk about bridging human and machine learning using discrete Markov chain Monte Carlo with people, and we're going to use this to explore the structure of human categories.
So the Pascal funding went to basically, uh, paying for my postdoc salary for six months.

So basically, the approach of this.
Work is in line with this work in cognitive science that uses computer science and machine learning methods to understand how the mind works, and in particular, Oh no.

Sorry, and in particular the the in particular the question that we try to address using these computer science methods is the challenge that the mind has, which is what they might have to do is it has to take noisy, uncertain and ambiguous input from the world and it has to extract useful, meaningful structure that underlies this noisy input, and so that's the underlying challenge that computer science methods have used to try to understand.
And so, for example, here's some examples of the types of challenges the brain and the mind face.
Like for example, you have to construct 3D representations from 2D images that hit the retina.
You have to recognize complex sounds from sound pressure waveforms that hit the air, hit the ear you have to.

In psychology, you have to learn languages from just hearing a limited set of sentences, which is a really small subset of all the possible sentences that are allowed in language and you are able to learn language this way.
We learn categories from just seeing a few limited examples from the category.
So there are lots of examples of where we as beings have to infer structure in noisy environments.
So the use of Bayesian probability theory and machine learning methods to address this question and cognitive science has been used in three principle ways.
So the three main ways that you can use probabilistic methods in machine learning for cognitive science problems are first as a benchmark.
So what you can do is you can take machine learning probability theory to answer, impose what the ideal rational solution would be to a given cognitive problem, which is what's the ideal learner or.
Rational thinker, what would they do in this noisy probabilistic environment and you come up with that ideal rational solution?
And then you compare that with actual psychological behavior and the any similarities or discrepancies between these two can be used to infer some principles underlying how the mind works.
So that's one way you can use probabilistic models as a benchmark for ideal rational behavior.

Another way that these models are often used is that they're used as a direct model of the psychological process, so you can use these and say maybe this actually simulates something like the algorithms that the brain is using.
The 3rd way is also we can use these methods, computer science methods as tools for measuring psychological mental representations without any assumption about.
The principles underlying them, or the algorithms underlying them, says just use the tools for measuring complex representations in the brain.
So today my project is going to be looking at this third way of applying computer science to cognitive science question.
And I'm going to look at it in terms of identifying how this how we represent the structure of human categories.
So it's going to be used as a tool for investigating human categories.

So two types are very Canonical models of category representation.
People have used in cognitive science.
They're known as prototype and exemplar models.
And so prototype models are assumed that you represent your category as just the iconic prototype of that category.
So you just pick 11 representation.

That kind of captures the essence of the features of that category, and on the other extreme people, other researchers proposed that you have this exemplar model, where really categories are representations of all the members of that category, and what happens is these two.

Different ways of categorizing new items so when a new item comes along and you want to categorize the new item, the prototype model says you're going to compare that that new item to the prototype only and how similar it is to the prototype will determine how likely it is the new item belongs to that category that you're assessing, whereas the exemplar model says when you encounter a new item, you will compare that new items to every single example of that category that you have in your head, and then the similarity between the new example and.
All existing examples of the category will be used to determine category membership.
So it's kind of too extreme views, but of course these models can somewhat be combined.

Preferences for products compared to the normal pairwise random choice.
